Communication Efficiency. In evaluating the communication efficiency of both baselines and BCRS, we record the time to reach target accuracy for each algorithm on CIFAR-10 as illustrated in TableÂ 3. It can be observed that thereâ€™s a huge difference between the accumulated Mâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹Tâ€‹iâ€‹mâ€‹eğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘’MinTime and Mâ€‹aâ€‹xâ€‹Tâ€‹iâ€‹mâ€‹eğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘’MaxTime, highlighting the need to mitigate the straggler problem. To achieve 40% accuracy, FedAvg, as a standard baseline, required approximately 3677.238 seconds to reach this accuracy level. Under Câ€‹R=0.1ğ¶ğ‘…0.1CR=0.1, the TOPK and EFTOPK algorithms demonstrated comparable efficiency, taking about 281.364 seconds and 157.412 seconds, respectively. In stark contrast, our BCRS algorithm significantly improves performance efficiency, achieving the target accuracy in just 17.938 seconds, much faster than the baselines.
Fig.Â 6 displays the breakdown of each process in one FL round and our BCRS algorithm effectively mitigates the communication overhead.
To clarify, blanks in TableÂ 3 do not mean missing experiments but indicate instances that are not applicable to the experiments. Blanks in the Mâ€‹aâ€‹xâ€‹Tâ€‹iâ€‹mâ€‹eğ‘€ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘’MaxTime and Mâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹Tâ€‹iâ€‹mâ€‹eğ‘€ğ‘–ğ‘›ğ‘‡ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘’MinTime columns for BCRS indicate non-applicability since the BCRS algorithm is designed to equalize client communication time. Therefore, specific maximum and minimum time measurements are not meaningful and thus omitted from TableÂ 3.

It is imperative to underscore that the evaluation of all algorithms was simulated under random bandwidth and latency conditions. It is advisable to draw comparisons between the recorded Compressed Time and the corresponding accumulated Maximum time and Minimum time for each algorithm. TableÂ 3 also reflects an intriguing balance between communication overhead and convergence rate. Employing a compression ratio does not directly translate to a proportional acceleration in the convergence rate. This finding further indicates the BCRS algorithmâ€™s significant advantage in both ensuring accuracy and reducing the communication overhead.
FigureÂ 10 illustrates the relationship between accuracy and accumulated communication time under various settings. Notably, our BCRS algorithm demonstrates superior performance, achieving high accuracy with significantly reduced accumulated communication time compared to FedAvg and other baseline methods.

references: In evaluating our OPWA algorithm, the focus is on the significant role played by the parameter enlarge rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma. We explore a range of Î³ğ›¾\gamma values, from 1 up to the total number of clients (Nğ‘N), to gauge their effect on the algorithmâ€™s performance. The training curves for OPWA with different Î³ğ›¾\gamma configurations are shown in Figure.Â 11. We observe that the optimal Î³ğ›¾\gamma value is not necessarily within a certain candidate range. To better illustrate this observation, we select three representing values of Î³ğ›¾\gamma, i.e. Î³=3,5,7ğ›¾357\gamma=3,5,7, and summarize the recorded accuracies and FedAvgâ€™s accuracy in TableÂ 4.

Optimal Î³ğ›¾\gamma selection. We can observe in TableÂ 4 that the optimal enlarge rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma is not confined to the range [1, |St|subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡\left|S_{t}\right|] (which corresponds to the number of clients selected). When the best value of Î³ğ›¾\gamma falls in [111, |St|subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡\left|S_{t}\right|], we interpret it as the scenario where the updates of parameters with a low degree of overlap are insufficient due to the averaging process. On the other hand, the best enlarge rate Î³ğ›¾\gamma falling in the range [|St|+1subscriptğ‘†ğ‘¡1\left|S_{t}\right|+1, Nğ‘N] is intriguing. It may suggest a balance between finding Î³ğ›¾\gamma and the optimal server learning rate Î±ğ›¼\alpha and the learning rate Î·ğœ‚\eta. In this context, the larger enlarge rates compensate for Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î·ğœ‚\eta that are not perfectly tuned for the FL environment.
